data.data:
[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-25] Somar Meteorologia reported Minas Gerais coffee zone received 62.8 mm of rain (138% of historical average) for the week ending Feb 13. [2026-02-24] Inmet data shows Lavras (South of Minas) recorded 330.0 mm of rain in February, 85% above the historical average. [2026-02-20] Arabica prices hit 7-month lows as Conab cites 'ample rainfall' supporting a record 2026 harvest forecast of 66.2 million bags. [2026-02-26] AccuWeather forecasts rain/thunderstorms through Feb 27, transitioning to clearer skies by the weekend.
[ANALYSIS]: Meteorological data from Somar and Inmet confirms a significant moisture surplus in Minas Gerais, with Lavras recording 330mm (85% above average). This precipitation is agronomically well-timed for the current bean-filling stage, directly validating Conab's projection of a record 66.2 million bag harvest. While the previous analysis correctly identified the crop stage, it failed to account for the potential quality risks of 330mm of rain (waterlogging); however, the AccuWeather forecast for clearing skies suggests a necessary drying period that mitigates fungal risks. The correlation between these specific weather patterns and the reported 7-month price lows confirms that the market is pricing in a supply glut driven by ideal yield conditions.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-26] USD/BRL at 5.1258 (+1.07% MoM) (Trading Economics); [2026-02-24] New crop sales at 36% vs 43% historical average, delayed by low exchange rate (Cultivar Magazine); [2026-02-23] Central Bank holds Selic at 15% but signals easing cycle starting in March (StoneX / Agência Brasil).
[ANALYSIS]: Current BRL strength is effectively throttling supply, as evidenced by farmer sales trailing the historical average by 7 percentage points due to unattractive local prices. This withholding provides a short-term floor for USD-denominated coffee prices. However, the previous assessment overlooked the forward-looking implication of the Central Bank's signal to cut the 15% Selic rate starting in March. Monetary easing typically weakens the currency; a depreciating Real would boost local-currency returns, likely triggering a release of the withheld inventory (the 36% vs 43% gap) into the export market. Thus, while current FX dynamics are supportive, the looming policy pivot introduces significant supply-side risk, preventing a bullish outlook.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: NEUTRAL]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-25] CMA CGM announced Asia-Europe services will return to the Cape of Good Hope due to 'uncertain international context', confirming sustained 40-45 day transit times. [2026-02-19] Port of Santos handled a record 12.7 million tonnes in Jan 2026 (+9.5% YoY), driven by a 79.6% surge in soy exports. [2026-02-24] EU officially confirmed the EUDR application delay to Dec 30, 2026. [2026-02-12] Santos vessel waiting times are moderate at ~2 days, but yard utilization is elevated (63-77%).
[ANALYSIS]: The outlook is defined by a counterbalance between easing regulatory pressure and hardening physical logistics. The official confirmation of the EUDR delay to December 2026 removes a primary bullish catalyst, eliminating the immediate need for panic buying or front-loading of inventory in early 2026. However, the physical movement of goods faces structural headwinds: CMA CGM's strategic reversal to the Cape of Good Hope confirms that extended transit times (40-45 days) are a long-term reality rather than a temporary disruption, effectively reducing global container rotation speed. Additionally, the 79.6% surge in soy exports at Santos is directly correlating with elevated yard utilization (63-77%), indicating that while vessel berthing is manageable, landside infrastructure is saturated, creating competition for trucking and equipment. The sentiment remains Neutral as the bearish removal of the EUDR demand wall is offset by the bullish floor of high logistics costs and transit delays.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.65
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: NEUTRAL]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-10] Logistics data indicates that 55% of vessels at Brazilian ports experienced delays or schedule changes, preventing the shipment of roughly 602,000 bags per month (Source: MercoPress / Cecafé). [2026-02-12] Cecafé reported January green coffee exports fell 30.74% year-on-year to 2.53 million bags, with Arabica specifically declining 29.01% (Source: CocoaIntel). [2026-02-26] The Containerized Freight Index traded flat at 1251.46 points, reflecting a 14.16% decline over the last 30 days (Source: Trading Economics).
[ANALYSIS]: The convergence of a 55% vessel delay rate and a 30.74% year-on-year collapse in exports confirms that logistical bottlenecks at the Port of Santos are actively restricting global supply. While the 14.16% drop in the Containerized Freight Index suggests easing global shipping costs, this macro trend is decoupled from the localized infrastructure failure in Brazil, which is trapping approximately 602,000 bags of coffee per month. This physical restriction creates an immediate supply deficit in destination markets, overriding the theoretical bearishness of lower freight rates. The data indicates a hard supply constraint rather than a lack of product, supporting a bullish price outlook.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BULLISH]

[EVIDENCE]: ['ICE Arabica certified stocks recorded at 453,612 bags on Feb 25, 2026, a daily decrease from 455,420 bags, but Pending Grading stocks increased by 7,395 bags to 171,080 bags (StoneX/MacroMicro).', "The Arabica futures curve remains in 'clear and consistent backwardation' as of Feb 23, 2026, with March 2026 priced at 281.15 cents/lb versus March 2028 at 244.95 cents/lb (CocoaIntel).", "Brazil's Conab projects a record 2026 coffee production of 66.2 million bags, a 17.2% year-over-year increase (Nasdaq).", 'Global green bean exports rose 9.2% year-over-year in December 2025, and the ICO Composite Indicator Price fell 2.6% in January 2026 (Global Coffee Report).']
[ANALYSIS]: The market outlook is assessed as BEARISH, driven by strong fundamental supply indicators that outweigh mixed short-term technicals. While the daily draw in certified stocks (Feb 25) suggests minor immediate demand, the significant increase in 'Pending Grading' stocks (+7,395 bags to 171,080) signals a substantial 'wall of supply' entering the exchange, directly supporting the bearish thesis. This inventory build aligns with Conab's forecast of a record Brazilian crop (+17.2%) and the reported 9.2% rise in global exports. The previous analysis flawed relied on external data regarding stock trends from Feb 18; correcting for this, the current evidence still points to oversupply. However, the persistent backwardation in the futures curve (Mar '26 premium) serves as a critical risk factor, indicating that while the long-term supply is heavy, immediate physical tightness has not yet fully dissipated.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: 1) XSentimentSentinel: Unusual X activity spike of 19 posts vs baseline 4.8, sentiment_score 4.72 with confidence 0.31; top themes include 'Price declines and futures dropping', 'Abundant Brazilian supply pressuring prices', and 'Technical consolidation at support'. 2) [2026-02-26] Arabica coffee futures fell to 283.16 USd/Lbs, a 0.44% decline from previous day and 22.9% drop over past month (source: Trading Economics). 3) StoneX analysts estimated 2026/27 Brazilian coffee crop at record 70.7 million 60kg bags, with Arabica up 29.3% to 47.2 million bags (source: FinancialContent / StoneX). 4) [2026-02-25] ICE-monitored Arabica inventories at 455,420 bags, recovering from multi-year lows (source: MacroMicro / ICE). 5) [2026-02-24] Minas Gerais received 62.8 mm rain, 138% of historical average, supporting harvest expectations (source: Nasdaq / Somar Meteorologia).
[ANALYSIS]: Critique: 1) The analysis shows mild confirmation bias by emphasizing bearish elements (e.g., price drops, supply abundance) while downplaying the recovering inventories as a potential short-term bullish signal of stabilization; no strong recency bias, as monthly trends are considered, but causation is appropriately correlative rather than falsely causal (e.g., rain supports harvest but doesn't directly 'cause' price drops). 2) All claims are backed by specific, cited sources without vagueness. 3) The bearish sentiment tag is justified, as evidence converges on downward price pressure from supply factors outweighing inventory recovery. Revised Analysis: The XSentimentSentinel alert indicates bearish social sentiment on price declines and Brazilian supply, corroborated by a 0.44% daily and 22.9% monthly price drop to 283.16 USd/Lbs, driven by StoneX's record 2026/27 crop forecast (70.7 million bags total, 47.2 million Arabica) and supportive rainfall in Minas Gerais (138% of average). While ICE inventories have recovered to 455,420 bags from lows, suggesting easing tightness, this does not offset the surplus outlook, pointing to sustained bearish pressure on Arabica prices absent demand-side catalysts.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-26] Coffee prices fell to 282.89 USd/Lbs, down 0.53% from the previous day, tracking a 22.97% decline over the past month. (source: Trading Economics); [2026-02-25] The 200-day Simple Moving Average (SMA) for US Coffee C Futures is explicitly valued at 304.82. (source: Investing.com); [2026-02-25] Technical analysis noted a bullish RSI divergence as Coffee C futures tested the 280 support zone. (source: TradingView); [2026-02-23] Technical analysis identified a key medium-term resistance level at 342 following a breakdown from a horizontal trend channel. (source: Investtech); [2026-02-05] Brazil's Conab projected a record 2026 coffee production of 66.2 million bags, up 17.2% year-over-year. (source: Conab / Barchart)
[ANALYSIS]: The original analysis is sound with no major logical fallacies: it avoids confirmation bias by acknowledging the bullish RSI divergence despite the bearish trend, recency bias by incorporating the 200-day SMA for long-term context, and false causation by linking supply projections directly to price pressure without unsubstantiated claims. Sources are specific and cited throughout, with no vague assertions. The bearish sentiment tag is justified by the price below the 200-day SMA, monthly decline, and supply overhang, though tempered by short-term bullish signals. To improve, the analysis now explicitly weighs the RSI divergence's limited impact against fundamental supply dominance, and notes that while a bounce from 280 support is possible, sustained reversal would require breaking above the 200-day SMA and demand catalysts, which are absent.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-26] Coffee prices (Arabica) down ~23% month-over-month to ~282.89 USd/Lbs (15-month lows); Implied Volatility (IV) is at the lower end of the 52-week range despite extreme historical volatility; Market remains in backwardation (Front month premium over deferred, e.g., KCH7 @ 269.20).
[ANALYSIS]: The previous analysis correctly identified the opportunity in 'cheap' premiums but failed to adequately weight the risk of the prevailing bearish momentum (23% decline). The revised view acknowledges that while the trend is sharply negative, the persistence of backwardation signals that physical supply tightness has not resolved, creating a divergence between technical selling and fundamental reality. The 'cheap' IV environment makes purchasing upside convexity (Long Calls) the most capital-efficient way to fade the move, as it defines risk against a continued crash while positioning for a snap-back rally driven by the structural tightness. The trade is a contrarian mean-reversion play, justified specifically by the asymmetry of underpriced option premiums at a 15-month price support level.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.65
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BULLISH]

data.title: How many Fed rate cuts in 2026?
How much revenue will the U.S. raise from tariffs in 2025?

query_results.top_post: Arabica calendar spread inversion has been easing as prices drop toward Brazil’s harvest: front month (H/K) fell from ~17c a month ago to ~5c now in K/N. Likely reflects expectations that abundant Brazilian supply could replenish stocks.

top_themes: Past price surges and climate supply risks

query_results.top_post: Arabica calendar spread inversion has been easing as prices drop toward Brazil’s harvest... abundant Brazilian supply could replenish stocks. (CoffeeNinjaRyan)
